54.42.text: Kusama is best known for her brilliantly coloured dotted surfaces, her installations with blow-ups

61.06.text: and her walls covered in brilliant spots.

73.36.text: And in her biography she talks about experiences, really, of a very young child, almost hallucinogenic experiences

79.52.text: where her vision of landscape and people was clouded by spots.

84.52.text: And in her very, very first mature works of art, just after finishing art school in Kyoto

90.12.text: the spot emerges as a pattern in her work.

93.08.text: And, from that period of time she comes back to the spot with great regularity

97.02.text: and by the end of the 60s she’s actually painting the landscape, she’s painting spots on people’s bodies

103.48.text: onto animals and the spot becomes a very regular motif throughout her work

108.90.text: It’s her way of, kind of covering the surface.

111.88.text: It’s a reflection of her vision

113.60.text: but’s it’s also a way of embracing the whole world in a, kind of, overall patten.

119.26.text: and, the interesting thing about this work in particular is that, where she’s moved

123.38.text: from creating an environment of spots that we passively appreciate or enjoy or walk through

130.79.text: she’s now moved on to actually involving the audience in the creation of this dotted, spotted interior.

142.70.text: I think Kusama is now seeing alongside people like Murakami or Damien Hirst or Jeff Coombs

148.62.text: as a, kind of, globally branded artist.

150.78.text: Her spots are ubiquitous and instantly recognisable.

154.40.text: They’re on the face of the London tube map at the moment.

156.84.text: Everywhere we go we see, to the biennials and triennials across the world you see

161.94.text: But what is also important to recognise is she really does fit into our history

165.94.text: and she was there in late surrealism, she was there at the birth of pop

170.96.text: she has a relationship to minimalism

173.04.text: she’s a real key practitioner in the beginnings of performance and action art.

178.26.text: So, she’s very much somebody who is an insider.

180.34.text: But she was never attached to any one movement for very long

183.72.text: so she’s always, also somebody who, kind of, is an outsider

186.64.text: she moves in and out of the, kind of, principal in avant-garde moments of the mid to late twentieth century.

199.42.text: And now she stands aside them because she’s got to that, kind of, got that status

203.90.text: where she’s a, kind of, unique, almost celebrity artist of our era.
